history.content: Honestly, take the internship and in your off time preview CS70 (going through lectures, discussion, HW), so when you take it for real in the Fall, it'll be a lot easier for you. Work experience is much more important for recruiting, and since you said it was your dream internship even better. I don't think Haas cares about CS70 either; they have their own class requirements.

children.subject: If its your dream internship... what are you hesitating for? Start learning cs70 as early as possible if you are worried about it. Good luck!
I personally found cs70 to be really rough over the summer just because it was going so fast and there was so much material to learn. It's your dream internship so you should take it! congrats :)

Before I read the rest of your post, I definitely think you should take the internship! Especially if it's one you're excited for. 

1. Curve is a little more generous in summer. Easier depends. If you're the type that likes to take 2-3 days off for w/e reason, this class isn't going to work for you. It's a constant grind. Yes, you get less problem sets, but it's still a lot of work and weekly problem sets. However, 70 will probably be the only thing you're doing.

2. I personally wouldn't worry about that because you can still crush CS 70 during the semester, but i'll try to answer to the best of my knowledge. I think an internship will definitely improve your skills as a PM, which will then make next year's search easier(PM internship on resume, experiences you can discuss in interviews, actual skills that can help land another internship/job). I can't say how recruiters think, but if you're going into PM work, I can't see DS vs CS degree affecting chances? Especially since you'll probably land another internship next summer that'll make you even more of a beast.

3. Oh no idea!

Conclusion: I think short term(first job, maybe second) your degree could be a detriment. But long term, your experiences(and possibly school name, but probably not) will be the main factors of getting interviews. However, if you spend these next X years becoming a beast PM'er, who wouldn't want a Cal PM'er beast?

As someone who's taken mucho summer classes, take the internship. They're worth having in your back pocket down the line, and even if you miss the GPA cutoff, that is an experience that could make the difference in an appeal.

Go for the APM internship. That's a no-brainer. It's way more valuable than declaring CS, given the company is also pretty big. People care more about work experience than your major/degree in the Valley

When I appealed in the fall after missing the CS cutoff (rip 70 final), my summer internship experience  played a big role in that process - my summer mentor wrote me a recommendation letter vouching for my passion and technical skills, and the internship helped further reinforce my passion for CS in a different way than my classes did which helped me write a much stronger essay. Admittedly it was an engineering internship and not PM, but I think like everyone else has said, the internship will benefit you more in the long run than taking 70 over the summer. Good luck OP, and congratulations!

I have a lot of friends, juniors and seniors, who are struggling to get an APM internship or full time role. If you wanted to make a post talking about how you were able to get this role, it could really help your peers!

history.content: I also agree with the student responses. Congrats on landing your dream internship!

children.subject: definitely internship :) if anything you can intern while following along with the cs70 material by yourself and then ace the class the following semester!

OP, I was in a similar situation but with a 6-month co-op instead. I decided to take the co-op and used the free time (which you will have a lot of, compared to school) to go through 70 lectures, discussions, and problem sets. This made taking CS70 a lot easier than it would’ve been if I had seen the material for the first time. It was a win-win. Declared CS (primarily due to studying the material beforehand) and got a bunch of work experience. Congrats!

history.content:
EDIT: I did accept the offer, thank you so much to all of the replies: they played an instrumental role in helping me make up my mind and trusting Piazza to "do its thing".

The original post:

I currently have an associate product manager intern offer from a huge financial services/payments company and it's pretty much my dream internship. The only problem is that I was planning to take CS 70 over the summer by itself in order to try to have a better chance of declaring the L&S CS major rather than in the fall while taking other courses at the same time. 

I have a few questions:
1. Is it actually easier to take CS 70 over the summer, or would it still be okay to take it in the fall with Prof. Sinclair and Prof. Song (provided that I would try to take a lighter course load with it)? Would my chances of declaring be hampered if I don't take it over the summer?
2. Is taking this internship more valuable than (God forbid it doesn't happen but) being able to declare the major? Is having a major brand name internship on one's resume and say a major like Data Science (not to say that this is a lesser major: it's just that there's no GPA requirement yet) more valuable than having no major internship this summer and hopefully declaring CS when it comes to finding jobs later on? 
3. As I also want to apply to Haas in the fall, would doing the internship be better than securing the better grade in CS 70 when it comes to the application?

Please comment below if you have any other thoughts on taking CS 70 over the summer (difficulty, material, pace, teaching, etc.) or the internship itself - any advice at all would be super helpful for me, especially if you did take CS 70 over the summer or had a similar dilemma.
Thanks so much!
history.subject: Internship Offer vs. CS 70 over the Summer
